titleStmt.title: Londons wonder; being a description of God's mercy and goodness, in the breaking of this late mighty frost which began about the beginning of December, 1683. and continued till the 4th. of February following. Great rich men hoardeth up their store as we may plainly see, in hopes to grind and gripe the poor in their extremity. To the tune of Packingtons pound.

Londons wonder; being a description of God's mercy and goodness, in the breaking of this late mighty frost which began about the beginning of December, 1683. and continued till the 4th. of February following. Great rich men hoardeth up their store as we may plainly see, in hopes to grind and gripe the poor in their extremity. To the tune of Packingtons pound.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for J. Deacon, at the Angel in Guiltspur-street,

notesStmt.note: Place and date of publication from Wing CD-ROM, 1996.
Verse: "This winter was sharp it did plainly appear,".
Imperfect: copy stained and torn, affecting title.
Reproduction of original in the British Library.
